especially learning right now at this

number one question that I've asked
myself is when I look at an item and I'm
thinking should I throw it out should I
keep it I ask does this item
bring me value does it bring value to my
life and if the answer quickly is no I
get rid of it if
I'm not sure maybe I'll put it aside and
come back to it most of the time I'll
end up tossing it out if something is
not bringing value to your life it's
just causing clutter it's physically
causing clutter and it's mentally
causing clutter and you just don't eat
it and if you don't need it you can
always sell it and make some extra cash
for those travels track your expenses
this is huge because a lot of us don't
really realize how much money we're
spending each month so go through your
expenses break it down by your set
expenses so those are expenses like rent
or mortgage phone bills insurance gas
like all the things you need to spend
money on every month and go to your
optional expenses those are expenses
like going out to the movies or eating
out coffee like the things that you
don't necessarily need but you want once
you see where you're spending you can
see where you can spend less ask
yourself for each item do I need this
can I possibly cut this out start a
money jar I love this one I've done it
several times and it's really helped me
save for travel it's important to put
that money jar somewhere where you're
going to see it every day and any extra
change that you might have from paying
for something money that you find your
pockets or purses or wherever scattered
around your house put that in your money
jar you can even make a pact with
yourself that you're going to put money
into that jar every single day it can be
a dollar or five dollars whatever you'd
like as long as you are continuously
putting money into that jar and seeing
it grow and will get you excited it will
make you want to put more money in that
jar start a dedicated travel fund go and
open a bank account that is going to be
dedicated just for money for your
travels you can set it up so that every
time you get paid from your job a
portion of that paycheck will
automatically go into that account you
don't have to do anything except watch a
graph cut things out this huge because
if you're going to places like Starbucks
every single day that really adds up the
coffee is like what say five dollars on
average if you're getting a five dollar
coffee every single day that's a lot of
money being spent on coffee
why not just make your coffee at home
and take that $5 every day and put it in
your money jar making more meals at home
is huge and what I've been doing is
every Sunday I prepare my meals for the
week so that I don't feel like
overwhelmed when I'm just busy worth
work or doing other things and I have to
make a meal then I just decide to go out
and get takeout or something because
it's easier I have all of my meals

it's cheaper and overall it's just a
